content:
This simple tool will help you find and use your most important views, like your work-in-progress views or any sheets that you are currently working on for a longer period of time. This is even more true if you are working in a workshared environment! You can have your Favorite Views always accessible and just a click away. You don’t have to mess with the cumbersome Browser Organization anymore!
It is inspired by the pin function available in some browsers, that let’s you pin any of your open tabs to the beginning of your infinite list of tabs, and keeping it in front of you wherever you are.
While this function can’t be exactly reproduced in AutodeskÂ© RevitÂ©, it is possible have something similar, just dock your Favorite Views panel above your project browser.
Layout # Buttons & Filter #At the top of the panel you can find the Filter bar, and at the bottom there are the buttons that let’s you Add or Remove a view.
View List #Inbetween is the list of your Favorite Views which are ordered by View Type and their Name. The views also have an icon that shows their Type. Hovering over a view a tooltip will show up, which contains some additional data about the a view, like their Type, or the applied View Template if there is any.
Functions #Adding a view #If you have nothing selected in the Project Browser the Add button will add your currently active view.
If you have selected one or more views in your Project Browser, those will be added to your favourites.
Removing a view #Similarly to addition, any view that is selected in your Favorite Views panel can be removed with the Remove button.
Filtering #You can also filter your favourites using the Filter bar at the top that uses a simple contains rule.
Opening a view #Just simply double-click any of your Favorite Views to open that view.
Saving your data #The data about your Favorite Views is stored in the actual RevitÂ© file, so you need to Save / Synchronize with Central if you want to keep your updates.
Loading your data #The data about your Favorite Views will be automatically loaded when you open a file or change to a view that is contained in a different file.
summary: Mark your favorite views so you can access them at any time.
title: Favorite Views

content:
For View Tracker, a Subscription is Required! See the parent page for details. Have you ever had so many views in so many files open that even colorized tabs couldn’t help you? (kudos to Ehsan for pyRevit ðŸ˜‰) Unfortunately there is a limit where horizontal lists like the view tabs get unmanageable, and you loose track of what you have open. The other built-in lists which are provided are quite inconvenient, and difficult to overview.
Then comes View Tracker to save your day!
This tool provides an user friendly way of managing your currently or recently open views. Your views will be organized in a simple dockable panel, grouped by their parent file. You are also able to collapse these groups to free up real-estate, and you can close any view or project if you wish to. You closed a view by accident? Don’t worry, we got you covered! Just enable Show Recent Views and you can see the views which were open in your current session.
This tool can be extremely helpful for BIM Managers, or any powerusers who have to deal with many files and many views simultaneously.
Layout # In the dockable panel you can see all your currently open views. They are grouped by their parent file, which groups can be collapsed. The views are sorted by their type and by their name. Their type is shown by the little icon on the left, and also in the tooltip, above their view template if there is any. Your active view is shown in bold. Your views will be automatically added once opened.
Furthermore the actual count of open views will be shown in the group header on the right in the following format: file / total.
Functions #Activating a view #Quite straightforward, just double-click on any, even if it is closed already, but still tracked as a recent view.
Collapse a group #Clicking on any group header will collapse or expand it’s content accordingly.
Closing a view / remove from recents #Middle mouse button clicks will close any open views, can be used to remove any recent views too.
Context menu #Using the right mouse button you can get the context menu which has the following functions:
Close View Closes the highlighted view
Close File Closes the file which contains the highlighted view
Show Recent Views Toggles the visibility of recent views
Clear Recent Views Removes all recent views from the panel
summary: Keep track of all you recently open views.
title: View Tracker
